loans.name: Saratt

texts.en: Mrs. Saratt M. lives in Kohs Nhae village in Takeo province. She is a traditional medicine seller. She is also a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Since planting her rice, Saratt has faced many obstacles, as her field is infertile and has had many negative effects on her crop.  She has requested this loan to purchase fertilizer, piglets for breeding and pig food.  Saratt is a 32-year-old widow with four children, all of whom are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, piglets for breeding and pig food

loans.name: Sijali

texts.en: Sijali R. is a married woman who runs a clothing shop in the Tandika ward of Dar es Salaam.  She purchases the clothing she sells from wholesale and retail shops in the Kariakoo city shopping center and from the Karume microbusiness city market.  Sijali has been in business for three years, and the income from her shop has enabled her to meet her family's daily financial demands and to pay school fees.  She is requesting a loan for TZS 1,000,000 to buy more clothing to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Komadia 1 De Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Composé de dix  femmes mariées, les membres du groupe KOMADIA 1 ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux, dans le village de SOGOLA de la commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI relevant de la troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de mariage. 
Pour mieux entretenir leurs exploitations agricoles afin d’améliorer leur production elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt agricole et tous les précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent acheter 15 sacs d’engrais dont 10 sacs de complexe céréales et 5 sacs d’urée, 200kg de semence d’arachide et des prestations de charrue pour labourer les exploitations (à savoir 4 hectares d’arachide et 3 hectares de maïs). Tous les intrants agricoles seront achetés sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. 
En fin de campagne, elles comptent sur une production totale de 3 tonnes d’arachide graine et 9 tonnes de maïs. La consommation familiale va prendre une partie dans cette  production et  le reste sera vendu au comptant sur le marché BOUGOUNI pour les permettre de rembourser le prêt et supporter certaines charges familiales. 
Ces femmes espèrent obtenir un bénéfice de 350 000 FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera  utilisé pour soutenir les frais d’entretien des enfants.
texts.en:
Composed of ten married women, the group KOMADIA 1 has members averaging 42 years of age and 6 children. The women all live in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children, and spouses in the village of SOGOLA, in the town of BOUGOUNI, belonging to the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women know one another by ties of marriage. To maintain their farms better, in order to improve their production, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their fifth farm loan. All the preceding ones have been correctly repaid. With this loan, they intend to buy 15 sacks of fertilizer, including 10 sacks of a blend for grains, 5 sacks of urea, 200 kg of peanut seeds, and plowing services to work the fields (namely 4 hectares of peanuts and 3 hectares of corn). All farm supplies will be purchased at the BOUGOUNI marketplace. At the end of the planting campaign, the group members plan on a total production of 3 tonnes of peanuts and 9 tonnes of corn. Home consumption will take up a portion of this production, and the rest will be sold in cash at the BOUGOUNI marketplace in order to allow for the repayment of the loan and for covering certain family expenses. These women hope to obtain a profit of 350,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting campaign. The profit will be used towards the costs of raising children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Planting, farm supplies, and the cost of labor

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing sells charcoal at her house. She has been in this business for the past six years and she has been borrowing from LAPO for the past two years. Blessing is very determined and optimistic about the growth of her business and the prosperity of her family. She is 36 years old and married with seven children. Blessing hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more charcoal to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is happily married with one kid and she is 32 years old. Grace sells provisions and foodstuffs. She lives in Lagos and she has been in the business for the past two years. Grace has been borrowing from LAPO for the past two years and she is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all KIVA lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Mrs. Chuon Y. is a farmer who lives in Phnum Lon Tas village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land on which to cultivate rice. Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to grow rice in the field. In order to deal with this problem, she is asking for a loan to purchase rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and to hire a laborer who has two oxen to plow the field. Her husband, Mr. Sam Saroeun, uses a horse and cart to transport goods and passengers. Mrs. Y. is a 42-year-old mother of five children, four of whom are old enough to be enrolled in the local school. Her husband and a child are shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and to hire a laborer

loans.name: Adjété Kokouvi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur pour subvenir à ses propres besoins  a entamé le commerce des huiles à moteur, il fait ce commerce depuis 2005. Faisant face actuellement à une baisse de son stock d’huile il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 10 bidons de 25 litres d’huile à moteur.
texts.en:
To support himself, this gentleman started off in the commerce of motor oil. He has been in this business since 2005. Currently facing a drop in his inventory, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy ten 25-liter drums of motor oil.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ten drums of motor oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more equipment

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
B. Damira is the leader of this group. There are women who do not wait until a knight comes to them on a white horse and offers his hand and support. They take life as it is and work hard to provide for themselves. Damira is of this type. At the age of thirty-one, she is not married. She has a father, an old retired man, whom Damira has been taking care of for years. To provide for both of them she works in a market, selling macaroni, buckwheat, rice, vegetable oil, and many other retail consumer goods. Three years ago she made a brave decision to go and work in Moscow, Russia. Being a thrifty person, she saved all her earnings and in the end returned home with pretty good funds. She opened a shop investing 1,600 dollars, bought a car, and celebrated her father’s jubilee. Now her monthly income is around 240 dollars. Damira would like to obtain a loan for purchasing more consumer commodities and sending them to the village. She has big plans for expanding her business. After achieving that, she is going to repair her house, prepare a dowry, and get married.

Damira’s partners are: Kyalbek, Cholpon, and Alfiya. Kyalbek is thirty-one. He is married and has four children. He prepares shish-kebabs in a café near a brewery. His wife works as a waitress in the same café. Kyalbek needs a loan to purchase sheep for feeding.

Cholpon is twenty-six. She has a husband and a son. Her spouse works at a construction site, whereas she keeps cows and sells milk and yoghurt. Cholpon wants to sell more milk, so she hopes to obtain a loan for buying one more cow.

Alfiya is thirty-one. She is married. Even though she has two small kids, she has to work to help her husband support the family. She sells underwear, women’s clothes, skirts, and pants. She needs a loan to purchase more clothing and also purchase provender for chickens and ducklings.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 Ps concept—People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (being profitable to grow further), and Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: For purchasing more food staples

loans.name: Chorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chorn C. is the group leader of a four-member group who all live in Rolus village in Kandal province. She is employed in a garment factory and also raises pigs. Since her pig-raising business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets to raise to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Khat Nak, is a soldier. This couple does not have a child yet. 

Three members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.

EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. An EOT loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise to earn more income

loans.name: Kodzo Anaté

texts.fr: Ce monsieur fait la conception de tableaux et de tampons qu’il expose après pour la vente. Il fait ce commerce depuis 2002, étant célibataire, c’est cette activité qui lui permet de subvenir à ses propres charges. Les matières nécessaires à son activité étant finies, Il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des fournitures pour faire les tableaux et les tampons.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who designs sign boards and stamp pads that he displays for sale. He has been in this business since 2002. Being unmarried, this business enables him to support himself. The basic supplies for his business are out of stock. He is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy supplies to make signs and stamp pads.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy the necessary supplies for his business

loans.name: Ghazni Group

texts.en:
Zeba Gul would like to take out a loan for her husband, who is a mechanic and is busy repairing different kinds of cars. Farida is a tailor and she wants a loan to buy a new sewing machine to increase her business. Shabana wants to take out a loan for her husband, who has a bicycle repair shop and will use the loan to buy necessary things for his business. Nazifa requests a loan for her husband, who has a fresh fruit cart. He wants to expand his business.

Zeba Gul is the leader of the Ghazni group. This group is made up of four women. All would like to receive a loan for the progress of their business. Finally, each member of the group thanks Kiva.

loans.use: For a car repair service

loans.name: Komadia 2 De  Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  KOMADIA  2 est composé de dix  femmes mariées âgées de 37 ans, ayant en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux  dans le village de SOGOLA, commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
Par des relations de voisinage ces femmes se sont connues.  
Afin de faire une bonne activité hivernale, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui  elles sont à leur cinquième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter 12 sacs d’engrais dont 4 sacs de complexe céréales et 8 sacs d’urée pour faire 4,5 hectares d’arachide, 5 hectares de petit mil et dix  petites dabas pour l’entretien des cultures. Les intrants agricoles et les dabas seront tous acheter sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. La production totale attendue par le groupe KOMADIA 2 est de 3,375 tonnes d’arachide graine et 7,5 tonnes de petit mil. Une partie de cette production sera destinée à la consommation familiale et l’autre partie sera vendue en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
Après le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, le groupe compte faire un bénéfice de 300 000 FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera  utilisé dans l’habillement des enfants.
texts.en:
The KOMADIA 2 group is composed of 10 married women of about 37 years of age, having on average 4 children and living in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children and husbands in the village of Sogola, township of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. The women met because they are neighbors.

In order to have a good rainy season business, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their 5th rural loan, all the preceding loans having been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan they expect to buy 12 sacks of fertilizer (4 sacks of cereal mixture and 8 sacks of urea) in order to grow 4.5 hectares of peanuts, 5 hectares of a local grain called “little millet”, and 10 little hand hoes to care for the crops. The agricultural inputs and the hoes will be bought at the market of Bougouni. The total expected production of the Komadia 2 group is 3.375 tons of shelled peanuts and 7.5 tons of “little millet”. Part of this harvest will be consumed by the families; the rest will be sold wholesale or retail, to the business-people of Bougouni.

After reimbursing the interest on the loan, the group expects to make a profit of 300,000 F CFA at the end of the growing season. This will be used to clothe the children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: agricultural inputs and small implements

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des articles de mercerie, elle a commencé ce commerce en 2007 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé où elle exerce son activité cela lui permet d’être plus proche de sa clientèle et d’avoir une idée de l’évolution du marché. La demande actuelle de ses clients est élevée, pour les satisfaire, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour augmenter son stock par l’achat de divers articles de mercerie ainsi elle pourra satisfaire tous ses clients.
texts.en:
This is a lady who earns revenues from commerce in sewing supplies. She started this business in 2007 and stocks up at the grand marketplace of Lomé, where she operates her business. This enables her to be closer to her customers and to have an idea of changes in the market. The current customer demand is high. To satisfy it, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to increase her stock by buying various goods for sewing and tailoring. She will then be able to satisfy all her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
Saleh is head of a family consisting of five members, He uses his car to distribute vegetables and fruit to houses and shops in the surrounding villages. He formally used to own small car and, last year, he received his first loan from FATEN of 1,000 USD and bought a better car than the one he had. 

Now, after repaying his loan in full and on time, Saleh requested another loan to do some maintenance to his car since this car is the only source of income for the whole family.

Saleh appears in the picture while applying for the loan at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To maintain the car that he uses for his business

loans.name: Komadia 3 De  Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Composé de huit femmes mariées, le groupe KOMADIA 3 regroupe des paysannes qui ont en moyenne 44 ans et 8 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux  dans le village de SOGOLA, commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
A travers des liens de mariage et des activités agricoles, elles se sont connues. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs productions agricoles et  prétendre à une autosuffisance alimentaire familiale, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur cinquième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt ces femmes comptent acheter, des semences, 12 sacs d’engrais dont 4 sacs de complexe céréales et 8 sacs d’urée  pour faire 3,5 hectares d’arachide et 2 hectares de riz. Tous les intrants agricoles et semences du groupe seront achetés sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. 
Elles  espèrent avoir une production totale en fin de campagne de 2,625 tonnes d’arachide graine et 3 tonnes de riz. La consommation familiale va prendre une partie de cette production et l’autre partie sera stockée et vendue en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
Après le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, le groupe compte avoir un bénéfice de 150 000FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera utilisé pour élever les  caprins.
texts.en:
Composed of 8 married women, the Komadia 3 group is made up of farm women who have an average age of 44 and on average 8 children. They mostly live in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children and husbands in the village of Sogola, township of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. They met because of being related by marriage and due to their farm work.

With the intention of increasing their agricultural output and hoping to raise enough food to feed their families, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their fifth rural loan after having reimbursed the preceding ones correctly.

With this new loan these women intend to buy seeds, 12 sacks of fertilizer (4 sacks of cereal complex and 8 sacks of urea) in order to grow 3.5 hectares of peanuts and 2 hectares of rice. All the agricultural inputs and seeds needed by the group will be bought in the marketplace of Bougouni.

They hope to have a total production at the end of the growing season amounting to 2.625 tons of shelled peanuts and 3 tons of rice. Part of this production will be consumed by their families and the rest will be stockpiled and sold wholesale and for cash to the business people of Bougouni.

After reimbursing the interest on the loan, the group expects to have a profit of 150,000 F CFA at the end of the growing season, which will be used to raise goats.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of seeds and agricultural inputs

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther sells sarongs. She has been in business for the past 8 years. Esther has been borrowing from Lapo for the past 3 years and the loans have been improving her business and her profit margin. She is 31 years old and married with 3 children. Esther is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas lives in Lagos and sells clothes. Dorcas is a single lady of 26. She has been borrowing from LAPO for the past two years and the loan has boosted her business. Dorcas hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more ready-made clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, bags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Leang Pork Village Bank Group

texts.en:
19 people living in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan group, and they will use the loan for various purposes.  Mrs. Leang P. is a 43-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows vegetables.  Her husband, Mr. Chea Yun, is a fisherman. He wants to expand his fishing business by purchasing a boat.  Thus, Mrs. Leang P. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory.  Three others are fishermen, and the last attends the local school.   

Four members of this group loan have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans.

loans.use: Various purposes, including purchasing a fishing boat

loans.name: Komadia 4 De  Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Au nombre de 7 femmes, le groupe KOMADIA 4 est composé de paysannes mariées qui ont en moyenne  32 ans,  4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux dans le village de SOGOLA, commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
A travers des liens de mariage ces femmes se sont connues. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur productivité agricole, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt ces femmes comptent payer les frais de labour, acheter, des semences  et 4 sacs d’engrais (uniquement de l’urée) pour 3 hectares d’arachide et 4 hectares de haricot. L’engrais sera acheté auprès des commerçants de BOUGOUNI. La production totale attendue par le groupe est estimée à 2,250 tonnes d’arachide graine et 1,600 tonnes de haricot. Une partie de cette production sera utilisée pour la consommation familiale et l’autre partie sera vendue en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
Le groupe compte obtenir un bénéfice global de 125 000 FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera utilisé pour soutenir les époux à subvenir aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Composed of 7 women, the Komadia 4 group is made up of married farm women who have an average age of 32 and on average 4 children. They all live in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children and husbands in the village of Sogola, township of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. They met because of being related by marriage.

With the intention of increasing their agricultural output, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their fifth rural loan after having reimbursed the preceding ones correctly.

With this loan these women intend to pay for plowing and buy seeds and 4 sacks of fertilizer (urea only) in order to grow 3 hectares of peanuts and 4 hectares of beans. The fertilizer will be bought from the merchants of Bougouni. The total production expected by the group is estimated at 2.250 tons of shelled peanuts and 1.600 tons of beans. Part of this production will be consumed by their families and the rest will be sold wholesale and for cash to the business people of Bougouni.

The group expects to have a total profit of 125,000 F CFA at the end of the growing season, which will be used to help their husbands support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying seeds and inputs and paying for plowing

loans.name: Yulia

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28 year old Yulia Makula from Mwanza. She is married and has one 4-month-old child. She is also responsible for supporting one dependent who is is an orphan. 
 
Yulia has been selling ornaments business since 2008. She works at the business for 12 hours per day 7 days per week. Yulia currently earns about $120 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 TSHS to purchase more ornaments and sell them to different customers. In the future, she plans to modify her business.Yulia thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro- Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more ornaments to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma  1 De  Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Composé de huit  paysans en majorité polygame, les membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMA 1 ont en moyenne  39 ans, 8 enfants et vivent tous dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs épouses, frères, sœurs et enfants dans le village de SOGOLA, commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
A travers des liens de camaraderies et de voisinage ses hommes se sont connus et font une même activité agricole. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur productivité agricole et satisfaire l’autosuffisance alimentaire familiale, ils ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Ils  sont à leur deuxième prêt agricole et le précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt ces hommes comptent acheter pour  13 hectares de maïs, 40 sacs d’engrais (dont 16 sacs de complexe céréales et 24 sacs d’urée), 15 bidons d’herbicides et payer les frais de désherbage. Tous les intrants agricoles du groupe seront achetés sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. Ils comptent sur une production totale de 32 tonnes de maïs. Une partie de cette production sera destinée à la consommation familiale et l’autre partie sera  vendue en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
En fin de campagne le groupe espère sur un bénéfice  de 350 000 FCFA  qui sera  utilisé pour soutenir les frais scolaire des enfants.
texts.en:
Composed of 8 rural men, mostly polygamous, the members of the Sabougnouma 1 group have an average age of 39 and on average 8 children. They all live in traditional extended families with their spouses, brothers, sisters, and children in the village of Sogola, township of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. They met because of friendships and due to being neighbors, and they all do the same agricultural work.

With the intention of increasing their agricultural output and growing enough to feed their families, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second rural loan after having reimbursed the preceding one correctly.

With this loan these men intend, for 13 hectares of maize, to buy 40 sacks of fertilizer (16 of a cereal complex and 24 sacks of urea), 15 containers of herbicide, and pay for weeding. All the agricultural inputs bought by this group will come from the market in Bougouni. They expect a total production of 32 tons of maize. Part of this production will be consumed by their families and the rest will be sold wholesale and for cash to the business people of Bougouni.

At the end of the growing season, the group hopes to have a profit of 350,000 F CFA which will be used to pay school fees for their children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: agricultural inputs and paying for weeding

loans.name: Ajike

texts.en: Ajike sells groceries and perfume from her home. She has been in this business for the past 15 years. Ajike is very happy with LAPO-KIVA for their financial support. She is 50 years old and married, and she has 4 children. Ajike is hoping for a loan of of N150,000 to purchase more groceries and perfume to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and perfume to sell

loans.name: Jenipha

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Jenipha M. from Mwanza. She is married and has three children between the ages of 4 and 10 years old. Jenipha  has been running a duka (neighborhood shop) where she sells common household and grocery items. She works at the business for 12 hours per day 6 days per week and is assisted by 1 employee. Jenipha  currently earns about $130 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 TSHS to purchase more materials and equipment. In the future, she plans to expand and modify her duka business. Jenipha  thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more materials and equipment

loans.name: Asror

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Асрор Хамрокулов 1963 года рожд. Имеет семью,5 детей. Жена Нигора воспитывает детей и  присматривает за скотом , которых покупает ей муж.Асрор откармливает скот больше 25 лет.Он каждую неделю бывает на скотном рынке и покупает понравивший скот и откармливает его несколько мес-в до готовности.Когда скот готов, он продает его на базаре за выгоду и сразу вместо него закупает новых.Таким образом они делают деньги.С нашей организацией он работает уже больше года.У Асрора постоянно должны быть на руках деньги,потому что на скотном рынке он бывает часто и занимается также куплей- продажей скота.Поэтому он обратился к нам за кредитом и не жалеет.
texts.en:
Asror H. was born in 1963. He has a family and 5 children. His wife, Nigora, raises the children and looks after livestock that Asror buys. Asror has been raising livestock for over 25 years. He goes to a livestock market every week and buys livestock that he likes, and then feeds it for several months until it is ready. Once the livestock is ready, he sells it at a market for a profit and immediately buys new livestock. This is how the family makes money. Asror has been working with our organization for over one year. Asror always has to have money available because he often goes to the livestock market to buy and sell livestock. This is why he came to use for a loan and does not regret it.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Ibijoke

texts.en: IbijO. sells drinks and wine. She has been in this business for the past 10 years and she lives in Lagos. IbijO. is 45 years old and she has 5 children. IbijO. is a single parent and she is trying to lift her family above poverty. She is requesting a loan of N50,00 to purchase more drinks and wine to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and wine to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma  2 De  Sogola Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe SABOUGNOUMA 2 est composé de huit  hommes mariés qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 5 enfants. Ils vivent tous dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et épouses  dans le village de SOGOLA de la commune urbaine de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
Ils se sont connus par des relations familiales et professionnelles. 
Dans le souci d’assurer l’autosuffisance alimentaire de leurs familles respectives et de se faire de l’argent, ils ont fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Ils sont à leur deuxième prêt agricole et le précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt ces hommes comptent acheter, pour faire 6 hectares de maïs, 30 sacs d’engrais (dont 12 sacs de complexe céréales et 18 sacs d’urée) et payer les frais de labour de charrues. Tous les intrants agricoles du groupe seront achetés sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. La production totale attendue par le groupe est estimée à 24 tonnes de maïs. La consommation familiale va prendre une partie de cette production et le reste sera vendu en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
Après le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, le groupe compte avoir un bénéfice de 275 000 FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera  utilisé pour soutenir les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The SABOUGNOUMA 2 group is composed of 8 married men who have an average age of 40 and on average 5 children. They all live in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children, and spouses in the village of Sogola, township of Bougouni, Sikasso region, Republic of Mali. They met because of family and professional relationships.

With the intention of ensuring that they grow enough to feed their respective families and make some money, they decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second rural loan after having reimbursed the preceding one correctly.

With this loan these men intend, for 6 hectares of maize, to buy 30 sacks of fertilizer (12 of a cereal complex and 18 sacks of urea), and pay for plowing. All the agricultural inputs bought by this group will come from the market in Bougouni. They expect a total production of 24 tons of maize. Part of this production will be consumed by their families and the rest will be sold wholesale and for cash to the business people of Bougouni.

After reimbursing the interest on the loan, the group expects to make a profit of 275,000 F CFA at the end of the growing season, which will be used to support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: agricultural inputs and fees for plowing

loans.name: Rahbar

texts.ru: Рахбар 1960 года рождения имеет, замужем имеет  3 детей.  Она торгует на рынке  женской одеждой , и другим домашнем обиходом.  О кредите узнала от матери, которая раньше получала  кредит на сухофрукты.  По совету матери она также обратилась  за кредитом и планирует пополнить полки своего магазина  новыми  сковородами и казанами и прочими хозяйственными товарами.  Также хочет на одной из стороне своей точки поместить швейную машинку и шить женскую одежду.  По ее словам женская одежда  покупается лучше чем хоз-нужды.
texts.en:
Rahbar was born in 1960, she is married and has three children. She sells women's clothing and other household items on the market. She has heard about the loan program from her mother who used to take out loans to buy dry fruits. She took her mother's advice and came to ask for a loan and plans to fill the shelves of her store with new pans, pots and other cookware. She also wants to install a sewing machine on one side of her vendor location to make women's clothing. According to her words women's clothing sells better than household supplies.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bedsheets and resell them to different customers

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane C. est un célibataire âgé de 30 ans qui vit chez ses parents dans le quartier Hérémakono-Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après les études secondaire et supérieure, il est resté pendant des années sans emploi. Alors il s’essaya à plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans réussite, il décida de faire de l’aviculture. Après 2 années d’apprentissage auprès de son oncle,  il maîtrise bien son activité.
Dans le souci de mieux rentabiliser son entreprise, Monsieur Souleymane C. décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter un stock important en nourritures pour les pondeuses et des poussins  destinés à préparer la relève.
Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso, et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Il s’approvisionne en nourritures à Bougouni et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Les œufs sont vendus, à la maison et au marché, à  une clientèle constituée de  détenteurs de boutiques  de vente d’articles divers, d’alimentations, de restaurants et de quelques particuliers.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Souleymane C. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 72 500 FCFA qui servira  à élargir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane C., age 30, is unmarried and lives at his parents’ place in the Hérémakono-Nord district of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After secondary school and higher, he remained unemployed for years. Then he tried several kinds of income-generating work without success. He decided to raise poultry. After two years of apprenticeship with his uncle, he has a good command of his business. Concerned about making his enterprise more profitable, Souleymane decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso to buy a sizable stock of food for hens and for the chicks destined to become their replacements. He is on his second individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso. The preceding loan was correctly repaid. He stocks up with food in Bougouni and in Bamako (capital of Mali). The eggs are sold at the house and at the marketplace to customers made up of shop owner selling general items and groceries, restaurant owners, and a few individuals. With this loan, he plans on realizing a monthly profit of 72,500 francs CFA that will serve to expand his enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food and baby chickens

loans.name: Jamolidin

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Абдуллоев Жамолидин-51 летний  семейный мужчина с высшим образованием, имеет 5 детей-все взрослые. Помогают родителям в бизнесе и по хозяйству. Основной источник дохода  семьи - это откорм крупного рогатого скота на дому. Жамолидин приучил своих детей присматривать за скотом и это нравится всей семье. Семья откармливает разный скот:  мелкий и крупный, быков и дойных коров. Дойных коров доят жена и невестки, дома постоянно есть молочные изделия и при том они продают молоко. Польза от скота большая и двойная. Наш кредит Жамолидин берет на покупку дойной коровы для своей невестки.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Jamolidin A. is a 51 year old man with high education, has five grown children. They help parents in business and household. The main source of income for the family is feeding of large cattle at home. Jamolidin has taught his children to look after the cattle and the whole family likes it. The family feeds different cattle: small and large, bulls and milk cows. The wife and daughters-in-law milk the cows and there's always milk products available at home besides that they sell the milk. The benefit from the cattle is big and in double. Jamolidin is taking out the loan to buy a milk cow for his daughter-in-law.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

loans.name: Tiéblé

texts.fr:
Monsieur Tiéblé C. est un  célibataire de 25 ans qui vit chez son feu père à Bougouni (troisième région du Mali) dans le quartier Torakabougou.
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très tôt il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus, notamment la métier de tailleur,  appris auprès  de son  père (alors en vie).
Avec 10 années d’expérience dans ce domaine il maîtrise bien son sujet. Tiéblé est aujourd’hui très sollicité et apprécié à Bougouni par toutes les catégories sociales qui constituent sa clientèle.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide  d’intégrer le programme  crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier  prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt,  il compte acheter une machine à broderie  à Bamako.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45.500 FCFA qui lui permettra d’améliorer son atelier, de contribuer aux dépenses de la famille et d’acheter un  lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Tiéblé C., age 25, is unmarried and lives in his late father’s house in Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali) in the Torakabougou district. Not having attended school, he soon became interested in earning an income, notably in the trade of tailoring, which he learned from his father (when alive). With ten years of experience in this domain, Tiéblé has a good command of his trade. Today, he is in high demand and much appreciated in Bougouni by all walks of life constituting his customers. In order to satisfy their continually growing needs, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan. With this loan, he intends to buy an embroidering machine in Bamako. He plans on realizing a monthly profit of 45,500 francs CFA that will enable him to improve his shop, to help with family expenses, and to buy a plot of land on which to reside.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an embroidering machine

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a young man who built himself by himself. After finishing high school, he opened small shop in Zboba Village and, with the income from his shop, he was able to finishes his B.A. degree. Afterwards, he managed a school canteen, then he opened a small clothes shop in Jenin, and then, in partnership with a friend, he opened a big shop for brides in which he sell and rents dresses and bridal accessories. Recently he finished his Master's degree and intends to get Ph.D. Ahmad is married and has four children. In the photo, Ahmad appears in his shop.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory for the shop

loans.name: Kifayat

texts.en:
Kifayat is applying to Kiva for a second loan. She needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy the spare parts for her husband's car. Her husband transports goods to markets. Her husband appears in the photograph.

"Thank you very much for the help."

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Баракабоев Рустам !968 года рожд. Проживает  в Джаборрасуловком  районе. Население района в основном  держат скот и Рустам также занимается откормом мелкого скота. Вместе со своей семьёй они держат стадо овец и пасут на пастбище каждый день. Рустам откармливает стадо 5-6 мес-в и продает их на базаре. «Самое прибыльное время для продажи овец – это  осень и зима» считает  Рустам и готовит своих овец к продаже.На наш кредит он намерен закупить ещё одну партию  овец и   оставить их на зиму.Он очень рад что сотрудничает с нами и может положится на нас в любое время.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Rustam B. was born in 1968. He lives in the Jabbor-rasulov region. Most of the population of the region keep cattle and Rustam also feeds small cattle. Together with his family they keep a herd of sheep and shepherd them on the pasture every day. Rustam feeds the herd for five to six months and sells it on the market. Autumn and winter are the most profitable time to sell sheep, thinks Rustam and prepares his sheep for sale. He wants to use our loan to buy another stock of sheep and keep them for the winter. He is very happy to be working with us and can rely on us in any time.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Diakaridia

texts.fr:
Monsieur Diakaridia Konaté est âgé de 36 ans marié et père de 4 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son feu père dans le quartier Faraba de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Suite au décès de son père, il revenait à  Monsieur Diakaridia Konaté (aîné de la famille)  de  prendre la famille en charge (conformément à la coutume). Très vite il commença les activités génératrices de revenus car il n’a pas été scolarisé.
Après avoir tenté plusieurs activités sans succès, il finit  par opter pour le commerce, notamment la vente de merceries  qu’il  a appris auprès de son ami.  Avec 8 années d’expérience, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité.
Afin d’obtenir un fonds de commerce complémentaire, Monsieur Diakaridia Konaté décide de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour une acheter de la mercerie à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Il  effectue sa vente dans sa boutique, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de tailleurs de la place et des localités environnantes.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Diakaridia Konaté compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 28 000 FCFA qu’il utilisera pour améliorer son entreprise et subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Diakaridia Konaté, age 36, is the father of four children. He lives with his wife and children in his late father’s house in the Faraba district of the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Following his father’s death, it came upon Mr. Konaté (the eldest in the family) to be responsible for the family (conforming to custom). He soon started a business to earn an income because he had no formal education. After having tried several kinds of work unsuccessfully, he finally opted for commerce, especially in sewing supplies, a business he learned from a friend of his. With eight years of experience, he has a command of his business and is much in demand. In order to obtain supplemental capital, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan. He intends to use this loan to buy sewing supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali). He makes his sales out of his shop to customers composed essentially of tailors in the area and from surrounding towns. With this loan, he plans on realizing a monthly profit of 28,000 francs CFA that will be used to improve his enterprise and to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Sesilia's Group

texts.en:
Sesilia is a member of the Uamsho borrower group. She is married and a mother of one child aged 10 years. She also cares for one other dependent. Sesilia started her own shop selling rice and wheat two years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of 180,000 Tsh.

This is Sesilia`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she has requested the amount of 150,000 TZS in order to buy more commodities. With the additional profit she will gain from the use of this loan, Sesilia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more items.

loans.name: Ibréhima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibréhima Sidibé est âgé de 36 ans et vit avec ses  4 enfants et son épouse chez son père à Bougouni dans le quartier Dialanicoro (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus. Depuis 15 ans il mène l’activité de fabrication de marmites à base d’aluminium. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son oncle. Monsieur Ibréhima a une maîtrise parfaite de son activité.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client de Soro Yiriwaso, il décide alors de rejoindre l’institution avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt  individuel.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 15 tas d’aluminium et 5 sacs de charbon  de bois.                                                                                                                                                                             Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali). La vente de sa production se fait à Bougouni et une partie dans les villages environnants lors des foires  hebdomadaires.  La plupart de ses clients sont des femmes
Monsieur Ibréhima Sidibé compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son entreprise.
Il a pour ambition de se construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibréhima Sidibé is 36 years old and lived with his four children and wife at his father place in Bougouni in the Dialanicoro district (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended modern schools, he started working to earn an income at an early age. Since he was 15 years old, he has been running a business making cooking pots made of aluminum. He learned this work from his uncle and has a good command of his business. Introduced to Soro Yiriwaso through another Soro Yiriwaso client, he thus decided to join this micro-finance institution and is now on his first individual loan. He plans on using this loan to buy 15 loads of aluminum and 5 sacks of charcoal. He stocks up in Bougouni and in Bamako (capital of Mali). Sales of his products are made in Bougouni and in surrounding villages during weekly fairs. Most of his customers are women. He plans on realizing a monthly profit of 32,000 francs CFA that will be used to expand his enterprise. His ambition is to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy aluminum

loans.name: Zahanati Group

texts.en:
Joyce M. is a member of the Zahanati borrower group. She is a 30 year old woman as well as a single mother of two children ages 12 and 1. Joyce started her own business selling CDs five years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tsh.

This is Joyce's first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she requested the amount of 200,000 in order to buy more CDs. With the additional profits she will gain from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money and expand her business. Naomi, Flora, and Subira are other members of the borrower group, and they are also requesting 200,000 each for their businesses.

loans.use: To buy more CDs

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Asha B. from Mwanza. She is married and 7 children between the ages of 14 and 36 years old. She is also responsible for supporting 2 dependents because their parents cannot fully support them.

Asha sells bricks for house construction. She started the business in 2009 and works 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, assisted by 3 employees. Asha currently earns about $200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 TSHS to expand her business. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Asha thanks you for supporting her!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah, age 30, is a member of the Tushikamane borrower group in Kola Morogoro. She is married and has a ten-year-old child. She also cares for two other dependents.

Annah started her own shop business selling rice, wheat, and cooking oil three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Annah's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 150,000 in order to buy more commodities. With the additional profit she expects to gain from the use of this loan, Annah hopes to save money and expand her shop business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her shop business

loans.name: Djénèbou

texts.fr:
Djénèbou K. N. est une veuve de 36 ans qui vit avec ses cinq enfants chez son défunt époux à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.(république du Mali)
Djénèbou K. N. mène cette activité d’achat et  de vente de bois de chauffe il y a maintenant 4 ans. Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout en hivernage, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. 
C’est ainsi, qu’elle a fait recours à ce deuxième prêt individuel (après avoir correctement remboursé le premier) auprès de l’institution pour acheter, deux chargements de camion “10Tonnes” en bois de chauffe dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre.  
Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis environ trois  ans, elle a bénéficié de plusieurs prêts solidaires  avec une association des femmes de son quartier, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèbou K. N. is a 36-year-old widow who lives with her five children in her late husband's home in Wayerma I, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (Republic of Mali).  She has been running this business buying and selling firewood for four years now.  She enjoys a great reputation in this business and receives many order, especially during the off-season, but her resources prevent her from filling them.  So then, she resorted to this second individual loan (after having repaid the first one correctly) from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to buy two "10Tonnes" truck loads of firewood from surrounding towns of the city of Sikasso, so as to satisfy her ever-growing customer base.  She has had an association with Soro Yiriwaso for about three years.  She has benefited from several solidarity loans with a women's association in her area.  All her preceding loans were correctly repaid.  She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will be used to help with family expenses, to cover the interest on her loan, and to invest the rest into her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Samaya

texts.en:
Samaya teaches English at a school. She needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy a computer and necessary books to improve her business. She is also an English home tutor.

Samaya is applying to Kiva for her second loan. She repaid her first loan successfully.

loans.use: To buy a computer and books

loans.name: Kansé

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kansé C. a 31 ans, marié et père de deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur C. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’initia  au commerce  de vente d’articles  divers. Actuellement Kansé opta pour une spécialisation en habillement et en alimentation. Il  dispose  de deux boutiques, une  de Prêt à Porter et une Alimentation à la gare routière de Sikasso. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y’a environ une  année. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel après  avoir remboursé  par  anticipation le premier prêt. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter, 8 cartons de biscuits, 4 cartons de mayonnaise Calvé, 8 paquets de boissons NBB, 3 cartons de savons, 4 casiers de boissons BRAMALI, 3 cartons du thé, 5 sacs du sucre, 5 paquets de bonbons, 5 cartons du lait NIDO, 5 casiers de boissons MALTA, etc. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement de voyageurs et surtout de routiers.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 350 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kansé C., 31, is married and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After having tried out several businesses without success, Mr. C. began selling various items. Presently Kansé has chosen a specialization in clothing and foodstuffs. He has two shops, one selling ready-to-wear and one groceries in the bus and truck stop of Sikasso. He is much in demand with his clientele because of the quality of his merchandise.

Wishing to satisfy his ever growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about one year ago. He is on his second individual loan after having reimbursed the preceding one early. With this new loan he intends to buy 8 cases of cookies, 4 cases of Calvé mayonnaise, 8 packets of NBB drinks, 3 cases of soap, 4 cases of BRAMALI drinks, 3 cases of tea, 5 sacks of sugar, 5 packs of candy, 5 cartons of NIDO powdered milk, 5 crates of MALTA drinks, etc. He buys his goods from the wholesalers in Bamako and then re-sells them retail to a clientele composed generally of travelers and especially transporters.

He expects to make a monthly profit of 350,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow his working capital, contribute to supporting his family, and pay the interest on his loan, investing any remainder back into his businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a member of the Uamsho borrower group in Kola Morogoro. She is 39 years old and is married. She is the mother of three children, ages four, eight, and 22. She also cares for two other dependents.

Asha started her own business selling charcoal 10 years ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Asha's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the profit she expects to gain from the use of this loan, Asha hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Geoffrey Mwaura

texts.en:
Geoffrey Mwaura is 36 years old and married to Ann Wanjiru. They have three children who are all in school. Geoffrey has been in the motorcycle transport business for four years and, on the side, has a small household goods shop in Naivasha town that is managed by his wife.

This is Geoffrey's second loan with KADET. He would like to buy more goods to restock his small retail store. He has plans to expand both his businesses and increase his income to a level where he can easily send all of his children through school and have a financially stable future.

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to empowering its clients economically by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To restock his household goods shop.

loans.name: Oumar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Oumar S.a 47 ans, marié et père de six  enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   Monsieur S.n’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer dans les études, vite il décide de s’initier à une activité génératrice de revenus. Il opte pour la construction métallique il y a plus de trente ans, depuis très jeune. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses prestations.
    Dans le souci de mieux  satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
    Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter 5 barres de fer U, 5 barres de fer Z, 4 paquets de baguettes, 5 feuilles de tôle, 4 rouleaux de file, etc. Il achète ses matériels dans les quincailleries de la ville avant de concevoir ses produits (des chaises, tables, bancs, etc.) afin de les revendre.
   Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Oumar SANOGO, 47, is married and the father of 6 children. He lives with his wife and their children in a big extended traditional family in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mr.S.wasn’t lucky enough to make a go of his studies, so he decided at an early age to start earning a living. He chose metal working more than 30 years ago, when he was still very young. He is much in demand with his clientele due to the quality of his products.

Wishing to better satisfy his ever growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his first individual loan. With this first loan, he is intending to buy 5 U-bars of iron, 5 Z-bars of iron, 4 packages of rods, 5 sheets of metal, 4 rolls of wire, etc. He buys his materials in the hardware stores of the town before creating his products (chairs, tables, benches, etc.) which he then sells.

He expects to make a monthly profit of 80,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow his working capital, help support his family, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy raw materials for his trade

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Dramane K. est âgé de 32 et vit avec ses épouses et leurs enfants  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  Dramane K.  après avoir tenté beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à  l’activité d’achat et de vente de bazins blancs, soude caustique, teintures, etc. depuis maintenant quatre ans. Il mène cette activité à Wayerma I en face de l’Agence Malienne pour la Presse et la Publicité (AMAP) de Sikasso, non loin de la prison centrale où il dispose d’une boutique. Monsieur K. est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux  ans. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel après  avoir remboursé sans difficulté le premier. 
Il compte acheter, 15 pièces de bazin, 10 sacs de potasse, 15 paquets de soude caustique et 10 boîtes de teinture de couleurs différentes à Bamako pour les revendre à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes teinturières de Sikasso et environs, en détail, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane K., 32, lives with his wives and their children in a big traditional family in Wayerma I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mr. Dramane K. tried out a number of businesses without success, then began buying and selling white “bazin” (a damask cloth used for local dyeing), caustic soda, dyes, etc. He has been in the business for 4 years now. He has a shop in Wayerma I opposite the Malian Agency for Press and Publicity (AMAP) in Sikasso, not far from the central prison. Mr. K. is much in demand with his clientele for the quality of his products.

Wishing to better satisfy his ever growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. He is on his second individual loan after having reimbursed the first one without difficulty.

He intends to buy 15 lengths of “bazin” (damask), 10 sacks of potash, 15 packets of caustic soda, and 10 boxes of dye of various colors. He will buy these goods in Bamako and then re-sell them to a clientele composed generally of women who do dyeing in Sikasso and surrounding areas, retail, for cash, and sometimes on credit.

With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow his working capital, help support the family, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of white damask cloth, caustic soda, dyes, potash, etc. for resale

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia, age 39, is a member of the Tuinuani borrower group in Kola Morogoro. She is married with two children.

Afia started her own clothing business four years ago. She works six hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 120,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Afia's second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested a loan in the amount of 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she expects to gain from the use of this loan, Afia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale

loans.name: Davena

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! 27-year-old Davena K. of Mwanza is married with one child of eighty months. She is also responsible for three other children who are unsupported by their parents. Since 2008 Davena has been running a shop where she sells electrical equipment. She works twelve hours a day, six days a week. Davena’s business currently earns her about $200 a month. She is requesting a 500,000TZS loan through SELFINA to purchase more electrical equipment. In the future she plans to expand her business. Davena thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken the lead as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through microleasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor support and access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of SELFINA’s microleasing program is that it allows clients to use tangible assets as collateral for loans, thus enabling clients to borrow larger sums.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical equipment.

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda, a member of Ushirikiano borrower group in Kola Morogoro, is the 36-year-old married mother of three children whose ages are 16, 13, and 12.  She also cares for two other dependents.  Three years ago, Emelda started her own cafe business.  She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 45000 Tanzania shillings.

This will be Emelda's first loan from BRAC Tanzania;  she is requesting the amount of 200,000 in order to buy more rice and wheat for her business.  With the additional profit she will gain from the use of this loan, Emelda hopes to save money to pay school fees, buy more food for the family, and expand her business

loans.use: To buy more rice and wheat.

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en: Adenike lives in Lagos and she sells sarongs, cosmetics and provisions. She has been in the business for the past 12 years. She is 45 years old and married with five children. Adenike is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs, cosmetics and provisions to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, cosmetics and provisions to sell

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is 60 years old and married with six children. She rents items like chairs, canopies and pots, and she has been in this business for the past four years. Roseline has been borrowing from LAPO for the past two years. She hopes for a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more chairs, canopies and pots to rent to her numerous customers. 
She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more chairs, canopies and pots

loans.name: Stephen Barithio

texts.en:
Stephen M. has been repairing electronics in Naivasha town for the last five years. He is married to Rachael Wanjiku and they have a 2-year-old child. Stephen was introduced to KADET by a friend of his, and this is his first loan with the organization. With this loan, he plans to buy tools for his trade and also to buy electronic spare parts. Stephen hopes to one day move into his own shop, since at the moment he is using rented space. He also hopes to become a supplier for both electronics and electronic spare parts.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities, in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy tools

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata C. a 39 ans et réside avec son époux et ses quatre  enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Fatoumata C. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à une activité d’achat et de vente  d’habillements teintés (bazins et foulards légers teintés) il y a plus de dix  ans. Elle met les bazins et les foulards légers en teinture qu’elle a appris auprès d’une amie. Elle dispose d’une place de vente à la gare routière de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de trois  ans. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BADEYA Sanoubougou I), elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel. Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
 Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 20 pièces de bazins, 70 paquets de foulards légers, 10 sachets de soude caustique, 10 boîtes de couleurs différentes et quelque chargements de bois de chauffe. Elle achète les bazins, soude caustique et couleurs sur place et  les foulards à Niono (région de Ségou) sur commande avant de les mettre en couleur afin de les revendre au comptant et crédit à la gare routière de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata C., 39, lives with her husband and her four children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After having tried out various businesses without success, Mrs. Fatoumata C. opted for making and selling hand-dyed clothing (damask and light dyed scarves) more than 10 years ago. She dyes the damask and the light scarves, as she learned to do from a friend. She has a sales point near the truck and bus stop in Sikasso, where she is much in demand with her clientele for the quality of her products.

Wishing to better satisfy her ever growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso more than three years ago. After three solidarity loans (group loans) with a women’s association in her neighborhood (Association BADEYA Sanoubougou I), she is on her third individual loan. All the preceding loans were reimbursed appropriately.

With this loan, she intends to buy 20 lengths of “bazin” (damask), 70 packets of light scarves, 10 packets of caustic soda, 10 boxes of dyes of various colors, and some loads of firewood. She buys the “bazin”, caustic soda and dyes where she lives, and the scarves in Niono (Ségou region) to order, before dyeing them and then selling them for cash or credit at the truck and bus stop of Sikasso.

With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 120,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to supporting her family, and pay the interest on her loan, investing any remainder back into her businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of damask for dyeing, light scarves, caustic soda, and dye

loans.name: Pendo

texts.en:
Pendo started her own clothing business selling clothes two years ago. She is a 24-year-old woman, married, and she cares for three dependents. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzanian shillings. Pendo is a member of the Tushikamane borrower group, In kihesa,Morogoro.

This is Pendo's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 150,000 in order to buy more clothes for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Pendo hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade sells frozen foods like fish, turkey and chicken. Folashade has been in this business for the past two years. She lives in Lagos. She is 38 years old and married with four children. 
Folashade hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more frozen foods like chicken and turkey to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
Iyabo sells foodstuffs. She has been in the business for the past 20 years. Iyabo has been with LAPO for the past two years and it is during this period of time that her business has really taken off. 
Iyabo is 50 years old and married with five children. She lives in Lagos. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Sitan

texts.fr:
Sitan D. est une femme mariée de 40 ans et mère de quatre  enfants qui vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
    Sitan D. mène cette activité d’achat et de vente de bois de chauffe et de poissons fumés il y a environ dix  ans. Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout en saison de pluies.
