loans.name: Milagro Group

texts.es: El grupo el Milagro esta conformado por Juana Esperanza L., Rosa linda F. R., María Nela N. A., María de los Ángeles
texts.en: The El Milagro Group is made up of Juana Esperanza L., Rosa linda F. R., María Nela N. A., María de los Ángeles

loans.use: Buy beef, corn, rice, chile peppers and firewood

loans.name: Gaviotas Group

texts.es:
Nancy M. es integrante de la Asociación Comunal  “Gaviotas” que es parte del Centro Focal “Juan Pablo” pertenece al grupo hace 4 años. Nancy en el pasado vendía aceite de auto, pero con el tiempo este negocio no generaba suficientes ingresos y decidió cambiar de negocio, ahora tiene una tienda de abarrotes vendiendo arroz, fideo, harina,  para lo cual necesita el préstamo y tener mayor mercadería.

Al igual que Nancy las demás integrantes de “Gaviotas” tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de ropa, peluches y comida y requieren el crédito para comprar mercadería (mantillas, ropa interior, arroz y fideo)
texts.en:
Nancy M. is a member of the Gaviotas Community Bank, which is part of the Juan Pablo Community Center. She has belonged to the group for four years. Nancy used to sell automobile oil, but with the passing of time this business did not generate enough income. She decided to change businesses. She now has a grocery store. She sells rice, noodles, and flour. She needs a loan to have more merchandise for her store. Like Nancy, the other members of Gaviotas have their own businesses like selling clothes, stuffed animals, and food. They need the loan to be able to buy merchandise (mantillas, underwear, rice, and noodles).

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Nuufou

texts.en:
Nuufou V. is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Vaovai. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nuufou owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Nuufou has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 360 WST a month from these activities.

In 2007, Nuufou joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nuufou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. Nuufou is now requesting a new loan of 1250 WST, which will also be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Nuufou plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Jesús Mi Proveedor Group

texts.es:
El grupo Jesús mi proveedor esta integrado por David Antonio P. A., María Teresa Z. M. y Martha Argentina V. G.. Ellos son provenientes del municipio de Diriomo que se localiza en la parte sur central del departamento de Granada, sobre una meseta que tiene a poca distancia las faldas del volcán Mombacho.

El coordinador del grupo es David Antonio P. A. de 38 años de edad el comenzó hace siete años vendiendo leche que distribuía en la comunidad y en granada y su medio de transporte era una bicicleta. Actualmente el vende leche y tibio de leche que distribuye en su moto.

El ya ha trabajado con Adim lo que le permitió mejorar sus ventas pero de la misma manera necesita de mayor inversión para su negocio que seria  en la compra de leche y pinol para vender posteriormente. Para P. su mayor desafío es que su negocio crezca y lo que más desea es prosperar y que su familia este bien.

Los otros integrantes del grupo son María Teresa Z. M. de 17 años de edad quien tiene cinco años vendiendo pan en su casa y en las calles  y Martha Argentina V. G. de 24 años de edad tiene tres años vendiendo plátanos.

Este grupo ha trabajado con Adim lo cual le podemos asegurar que son trabajadores, con iniciativa y con muchos deseo de salir adelante pero lo único que los detiene es no tener los recursos necesarios para invertir en sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Jesus Mi Proveedor (Jesus My Provider) Group is made up of David Antonio P. A., María Teresa Z. M. and Martha Argentina V. G.. They are from Diriomo Municipality, located in the south central part of Granada Department, over a plateau near the base of the Mombacho volcano. The group's coordinator is David Antonio P. A., who is 38 years old. He started selling milk in his community and in Granada from his bicycle about seven years ago. Today, he sells milk and hot milk toddies (a drink made from cinnamon, milk, rum and sugar), which he distributes from his motorcycle. He has worked with Adim perviously, which allowed him to improve his sales, but he still needs to invest a larger sum in his business to buy milk and pinol (a corn/cocoa-based powder used to make drinks) to later resell. For P., his greatest challenge is expanding his business. His greatest desire is to prosper and to ensure the well-being of his family. The other group members are María Teresa Z. M., who is 17 years old and has been selling bread from home and on the street for the past five years, and Martha Argentina V. G., who is 24 years old and has been selling bananas for the past three years. This group has already worked with Adim, so we can assure you that they are hardworking, with initiative and a strong desire to get ahead in life. Their only limitation is the lack of necessary resources to invest in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk and pinol (a corn/cocoa-based powder used to make drinks)

loans.name: Nery

texts.en:
Señora Nery has two business ventures. She prepares and sells typical regional foods in front of her home in the evenings and also does sewing work, specializing in undergarments. She is 40 years old and is a single parent to four children, two of whom are still minors. She lives with her children in the city of Pucallpa.

Nery has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about seven years and belongs to the communal bank "Nuevas Amigas" (“New Friends”). Nery invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in purchasing a semi-industrial sewing machine.

Nery plans to invest this loan of 1,200 soles in both of her current business ventures. She will buy food to prepare meals for her evening restaurant business and she will also buy materials for her sewing work.

Nery's goal is to improve the interior of her house in order to make part of it into a sewing workshop. She would also like to construct a better space from which to sell her meals in the evenings. Nery is grateful for the help she has received from Manuela Ramos, particularly because the organization serves women entrepreneurs who have few financial resources.

loans.use: To buy food for her restaurant business and materials for sewing undergarments

loans.name: Lealofi

texts.en:
Lealofi L. (0) is a 44-year-old woman living in the town of Vaovai. She is married and has six adult children.

Lealofi owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 380 WST a month.

In 2008, Lealofi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

Lealofi is now requesting a new loan of 1,250 WST which will again be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. The loan will be her 3rd from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Santa Ana Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL  SANTA ANA

La Alcancía Comunal Santa Ana  esta representada por su presidenta Rosario O. y lo conforman 10 socios de las cuales uno es hombre.
El negocio de la presidenta es de acuerdo a la necesidad del cliente, ella vende artefactos, calzado, cosméticos, negocio que heredo de sus tías desde hace muchos años.
Daisy B. es la tesorera y se dedica a la venta de comida “salchipapas” solo por las noches ya que durante el día ayuda a su suegra en la venta de comida. Ella tiene 2 hijos por los cuales lucha día a día.
La secretaria Rosa S. tiene una bodega desde hace 5 años que lo obtuvo mediante el apoyo de  sus hermanas y de sus padres, con mucho esfuerzo lo está implementado poco a poco ya que es la única furente de ingreso para ella  y sus pequeño hijo.

La mayoría de las socias se dedica a diversas actividades como venta de ropa, calzado, cosméticos, verduras y comida. El Sr. Ángel León se dedica a hacer taxi es casado con un hijo, y con mucho esfuerzo pudo comprar su auto y lo está terminando de pagar en cuotas mensuales.

Los socios conocedores de la competencia en el rubro comercial y de servicios, son muy optimistas y siempre piensan en la mejora familiar.

El crédito otorgado será para la compra de productos e insumos que les permita mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL SANTA ANA The Santa Ana Community Piggy Bank is represented by its president Rosario O. and made up of 10 members. One of them is a male. The president's role works according to the clients' needs. She sells appliances, shoes, and cosmetics. She inherited the business from her aunts many years ago. Daisy B. is the treasurer. She sells food such as “salchipapas” (sausage with potatoes) at night. During the day she helps her mother-in-law sell food. She has two children for whom she fights day-in day-out. The secretary, Rosa S., has had a warehouse for 5 years. She acquired it with her sisters and parents' support. She works hard everyday and little by little she's making it work since it is the only source of income for her and her small son. Most of the members have their own specialty such as selling clothes, shoes, cosmetics, vegetables, and food. Mr. Angel L. has a taxi. He is married and has a son. With a lot of effort, he purchased his car and is finishing paying for it with monthly payments. The members know the competition in the commercial and service industries. They are very optimistic and always think about ways to improve their families. The loan will be used to buy products and materials to improve their profits.

Translated from Spanish by Linda Zamora, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products and materials

loans.name: Fiva

texts.en:
Fiva L. (0) is a 50-year-old woman living in the town of Moataa. She is married and has four adult children.

Fiva owns and operates a handicraft business, selling general handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 300 WST a month.

In 2001, Fiva joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional handicrafts to sell.

Fiva is now requesting a new loan of 3,000 WST which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. The loan will be her 8th from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Señora Mariana sells cold drinks and clothing. In this photo she shows the few drinks left in her refrigerator following a heavy period of sales resulting from the Peruvian Independence Day celebrations in her neighborhood during the last week of July. Mariana is 53 years old and is married with three adult children. Mariana's husband works at the offices of the Pucallpa city government.

Mariana has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about six years and is a member of the communal bank "Nuevas Amigas" (“New Friends”). She used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in a small grocery shop that she had at that time.

Mariana plans to use this loan of 2,000 soles to invest in clothing which she will sell in the small communities along the Ucayali, the wiD. brown river which flows past the city of Pucallpa and joins the Amazon to the north. She will also use some of the loan to purchase beer and soda for her business selling cold drinks.

Mariana's goal is to re-establish her grocery shop. She also wants to maintain her business selling cold drinks. She is grateful for the financial assistance that she has received from Manuela Ramos. Working with the organization has also motivated her to keep moving forward with her business ventures.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell and also beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Aufaatasi

texts.en:
Aufaatasi J. is a 56-year-old woman living in the town of Saleilua. She is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Aufaatasi operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from cultivating fruit trees and harvesting their fruit for sale. Aufaatasi has been engaged in this business for more than two years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Aufaatasi  joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aufaatasi  has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Aufaatasi  is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Aufaatasi from SPBD. Aufaatasi plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Micaela Villegas Group

texts.es:
ALCANCIA COMUNAL
MICAELA VILLEGAS

La alcancía Comunal Micaela Villegas es un grupo muy unido conformado por 10 integrantes las cuales son personas puntuales, solidarias y positivas.
 
La presidenta María es madre soltera y tiene 5 hijos, ella se dedica al negocio de la Lonchera Escolar desde hace un año, y durante las vacaciones vende chompas y así puede ayudar en casa.

Eduardo es el Secretario del grupo, es  una persona muy hábil que se dedica a la venta de cerveza que es un negocio heredado de sus padres. Tiene como objetivo hacer de su negocio una distribuidora al por mayor.

Mary P. es la tesorera del grupo y tiene su negocio de fotostática, el crédito será destinado al mejoramiento de las máquinas fotocopiadoras.

Los demás socios tienen diferentes negocios como venta de prendas de vestir, crianza y venta de mascotas, productos de belleza, servicio de confecciones, etc. que gracias a los créditos pueden generar ingresos  ya que de ello depende el sustento de sus familias.
texts.en:
The Micaela Villegas Communal Bank is a closely-knit group made up of 10 members who are punctual, supportive and positive. María, the group president, is a single mother of 5 children. She has been operating a school lunch counter for one year. During the holidays, she sells sweaters to help with the home expenses. Eduardo is the group secretary. He is a skillful person who sells beer at a business that he inherited from his parents. Eduardo hopes to become a wholesale distributor. Mary P. is the group treasurer and operates a photocopying business. She will use her loan to upgrade her copying machines. Other members have different businesses such as selling clothing, breeding and selling pets, cosmetics sales, tailoring, etc. Thanks to the loans, they can generate income on which their families depend.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products & supplies

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Señora Virginia sells delicious regional dishes in front of her home in the evenings. Virginia is 52 years old and resides in the city of Pucallpa. She lives with her husband and the youngest of their three children. Virginia's husband is also an entrepreneur.

Virginia has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about 7 years and belongs to the communal bank "Nuevas Amigas" (New Friends). She invested her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in purchasing iron which she sent to the city of Tarapoto to be sold. Virginia plans to use this loan of 2,800 soles to invest in her small restaurant business and also to purchase more iron to sell in Tarapoto.

Virginia's dream is to build a large patio area in front of her house so that she can serve her meals in a space that is more pleasant for her customers. Virginia is happy to be receiving financial support from Manuela Ramos for her business ventures.

loans.use: Food for a restaurant business; iron to be resold in a nearby city

loans.name: La Peñita De La Segundita Group

texts.es:
Brígida V. V.

La señora Brígida V. de  ha iniciado la inversión en un  huerto de aguacates Haas en la pequeña población indígena llamada Donaciano Ojeda en el Estado de Michoacán. Ella ha solicitado este préstamo justamente para invertir en este huerto ya que tiene  planeado comprar otras plantas de aguacate, fertilizante orgánico para nutrir el suelo y para no dañar el  ambiente, también quiere tener dinero para pagar apoyo técnico que la asesore junto con su familia para eliminar plagas y enfermedades  de la manera mas segura y para hacer crecer de manera optima las plantas de aguacate en su huerto.  Es importante mencionar que esta región es muy prolifera en el cultivo de aguacates, ya que se obtiene fruto de muy buena calidad.  Además de esta actividad, la señora Brígida es artesana, borda servilletas y elabora artesanía de ocoshal (artesanía elaborada con fibra de pino que es recolectada en el bosque y es transformada en bellas piezas) 

La Señora Brígida esta casada con Don Vinicio el cual tiene como principal actividad económica  trabajar de cargador en la central de abastos de la Ciudad de México, esto le implica salir frecuentemente y dejar a su familia la mayor parte del tiempo. El nunca tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar y por esta razón el señor Vinicio de 32 años de edad y la señora Brígida de 30,  quieren que sus cuatro hijos estudien para que tengan mas oportunidades y en este momento lo que mas desean es tener capital para invertir en el huerto de aguacates y están seguros que ha mediano plazo esta inversión les brindará un beneficio económico. 
La Señora Brígida también tiene la esperanza de que este huerto de aguacates sea lo suficientemente rentable para que su esposo no  tenga que salir cada semana en busca de trabajo a la ciudad de México y que sus hijos puedan crecer teniendo cerca a su figura paterna
texts.en:
Brígida V. V. La señora Brígida V. has started a Haas avocado orchard in the small indigenous village called Donaciano Ojeda in the state of Michoacán. She has requested this loan for her orchard so that she can buy more avocado trees and organic fertilizer to nourish the soil and not damage the environment. Sra. Brígida will also pay for technical support to advise her family how to eliminate diseases and pests in the safest way and still provide optimal conditions for her avocado trees to grow. It is important to mention that this region is well known for its avocados, so the fruit is of the best quality. In addition to being a farmer, Sra. Brígida is a craftswoman who makes embroidered napkins and ocoshal (beautiful pieces made of woven pine fibers collected from the forest). Sra. Brígida is 30 years old and married to Don Vinicio (age 32), who works as a porter at a supply depot in Mexico City. He is away from his family most of the time because of his work. Don Vinicio never had the chance to study, so he and Sra. Brígida want their four children to explore and have more opportunities. At this time, they need the capital to invest in their avocado orchard and are confident that this will pay off financially. Sra. Brígida hopes that her avocado orchard is profitable enough so that her husband does not have to travel to Mexico City each week for work and that her children can grow up with their father around them.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for an avocado orchard

loans.name: Felicia Marleni

texts.es:
Felicia es una madre de familia de 37 años de edad que reside en el Sector El Pescador, distrito de San José, ubicado a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo – Perú, donde vive con su esposo y con sus cinco hijos: dos mujeres de 16 y 12 años y tres varones de 11, 4 y 1 año; cuatro de sus hijos estudian en el colegio estatal de la localidad.

Ella es propietaria de una pequeña Bodega – Tienda que se dedica a la venta de artículos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc.) y mediante la cual ayuda a sostener a su familia ya que su esposo trabaja eventualmente en pesca artesanal y los ingresos percibidos por él no bastan para la economía diaria.

Por primera vez ella está solicitando un préstamo de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de arroz y azúcar para ampliar sus ventas y asi seguir apoyando a su familia. En su comunidad, Felicia es muy conocida y respetada.
texts.en:
Felicia is a 37 year-old mother who lives in the El Pescador sector, San José district, located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo, Peru. She lives with her husband and 5 children: two girls who are 16 and 12 years old, and three sons who are 11, 4, and 1 years old. Four of her children are studying in the local state-run school. She is the owner of a small grocery store where she sells basic daily-use items (rice, sugar, cooking oil, etc.). Through this business she helps support her family since her husband works occasionally in artisanal fishing, but the income he earns isn’t enough for the daily expenses. She is requesting her first loan of 2000 PEN, which she plans to use to purchase rice and sugar to increase her sales and thereby continue supporting her family. Felicia is well-known and respected in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 15 100-pound sacks of rice and 10 100-pound sacks of sugar

loans.name: Srea

texts.en: Srea S., 29, is married and lives in the Batambong province with her one child. Daily, she is busy with her work raising pigs, making around US $2, while her husband, a construction foreman commuting from place to place for his business, typically makes US $3 each day. S. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US $1000 to purchase pigs to raise. Raising pigs is a good way for her to generate some extra income for her family, and she will be able to raise her standard of living. It is a difficult time economically for most Cambodians because inflation has soared. However, S. sees these pigs as a good opportunity for her to help her family and to make it through these difficult times.

loans.use: To purchase pigs

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda B. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Rosenda is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosenda owns & operates a business in the food sector, selling fish. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fish to local community members. Rosenda has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosenda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosenda is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosenda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell to expand offering

loans.name: Chamroeun

texts.en:
K. is 42-year-old married father who currently lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh Capital, in Cambodia Country. He is a local chef. He is always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies, while his wife works as a tailor who sews the villagers' clothes. She also shares her sewing knowledge with her trainees for a fee. The family includes five devoted children, four of whom are single and one is married. 

K. would like a loan of $800 in order to purchase a piece of land in good condition for a farming business. He will rent out this land to farmers for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda C. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Linda is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Linda owns and operates a business in the services sector operating a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing women's tailoring services to local community members. Linda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Linda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from GDMPC. Linda is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles, threads, etc. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Linda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles, threads, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new inventory such as cell phone accessories and spare parts

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea T. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Lea is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Lea owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Lea has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lea joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lea is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lea from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen sells RTW (Ready to Wear clothes). With her need of additional business capital, she would like to request a loan amount of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. This amount will really help her to improve her business. 

She is also thankful that through her business, she is able to help her husband in meeting the needs of their family.  Karen hopes that through the assistance of Kiva, she will increase her income. She hopes to maintain their good family relationship and live a progressive life.

loans.use: Additional capital to support her clothing sales business

loans.name: Mrs. Vouchnor Hok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank Group, which consists of 16 people, is located in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Vouchnor H. is the Village Bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a fish retailer in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more fish to re-sell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Tho Thang, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Mrs. Vouchnor H. is 34 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school, while the others are too young to work or study. 

Four members in this group loA. are End-of-Term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia, or Amy as she is called in her village in Inaban Dupax del Norte, is married to Rolly. They have seven children, four girls and three boys. Their two older children are college undergraduates and already married, while the other five children are still studying in high school and elementary school.  

The couple is in the farming business. They are striving hard to earn a living and to further support the education of their children. At present, Amy would like to borrow a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders. She will use the loan for the maintenance of their farm and to purchase enough farm supplies for them to have a good harvest. Amy hopes that someday, their business will grow and they can improve their living situation.

loans.use: Farm maintenance and purchase of farm supplies

location.town: Inaban Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza D. is from the village of Gala, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Liza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Liza sells banana in the local community. Liza has had her business for more than one year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP per month.

In 2008, Liza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Liza is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Liza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Sout Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people livI. in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province comprise this village bank group loan, and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Sokha S. is a 46-year-old village bank group president. She is a grocer who owns a grocery store. Since her business is doI. well, she wants to expand it by purchasI. more grocery goods to resell to earn more profits. Her husband, Mr. Chhorn Sarorn, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. The couple has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while three are attendI. the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. 

Four members in this group loan are End-of-Term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase grocery store goods for resale

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en: Nguon S., 42, is a flower vendor who sells different kinds of flower in the centre of Phnom Penh city. She started her business in early 2000 and currently makes around $2.50 USD of income per day. She uses her profits to buy food for her family and ensure that both her children attain the highest level of education. Her husband also supplies a source of family income through his work in construction. Since Nguon S.’s income is only enough to meet her family’s needs, she has a big problem with transport because she doesn’t own a vehicle. She is therefore looking for a loan to buy a used motorcycle. This new motorbike will allow her to reduce her transport costs.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda manages a hog-raising business in her rural village of Siempre Viva in Malig, Isabela. She is blessed with four children: Francisco B. Jr., Framelyn Jay, Fannica Kriza Joyce, and Fe Kristel. Due to lack of financial capital, she is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP through Kiva, which she will use to buy sacks of feed for her hogs. Her husband, Francisco, is a simple farmer, and his income is not enough because most of his harvest goes to traders from whom he gets most of the farm inputs he uses in farming.

Imelda is thankful that she is able to maintain her hog-raising business to help meet her family's needs, especially sending the children to school. Imelda hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her request to benefit her family.

loans.use: To buy sacks of feed for her pigs

location.town: Siempre Viva in Malig, Roxas, Isabela

loans.name: Sithon

texts.en: Mrs Sithon S. lives in Smorn Pream village in Takeo province. She is 37 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom works at a garment factory while another is a construction worker and the others are attending the local school. Mrs Sithon S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr Kol Saroeun, is a policeman in the local district. Since his workplace is far from the house, he has to pay for a motor taxi to get to and from work. Now Mrs Sithon S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to ride to work

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn B. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 32 years old. Marlyn is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Marlyn owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a bakery. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from baking and selling bread to the local community. Marlyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baking equipment. Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and for her daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional cooking ingredients for her bakery

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im S. is a villager in Boeung village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Keo Bo, are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice. On this plantation, they face an obstacle because they usually pay a lot of money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow on the field. Thus, Mrs. Im S. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding and to support the rice field. She is 57 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a policeman and the remaining is a farmer. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for breeding and to support the rice field

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeb P. lives in Ank Prasat village in Takeo province. She sells clothing in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Chhay Thy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Chroeb P. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice field, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy more clothing to add to her business. She hopes to increase income and improve the family living with this loan. She is 44 years old and the mother of five children, four of whom are attending the local school while the youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her husband's rice field and to buy more clothing to add to her business

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs Vanna L. is from Tuol Pang Ror village in Takeo province. She is a 26-year-old mother of two children who are too young to work or study. She sells duck eggs in the local market. Her husband, Mr Saem PhalL., is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he also owns an electric cow and is hired by other villagers to plow their fields. However, currentL. he faces an obstacle with his electric cow and Mrs Vanna L. has decided to ask for a loan to repair it. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To repair the electric cow

loans.name: Aun

texts.en: Mrs Aun O., 41,  is a determined woman and the mother of six children, one of whom is married while the others are of school age. She is shown in the picture at her vegetable store. Aun O. sells vegetables that she goes to buy with her husband from wholesale suppliers. She then brings them to sell to customers at the market. Typically, she generates $5 USD income each day, which she uses to manage all her family’s requirements and, in particular, to make sure her school-aged children get a good educatiO.. Aun O. says that her investment is growing well as she has an increasing number of regular customers. To make her business more successful and to satisfy customer demand, Aun O. has requested a loan to purchase larger quantities of various vegetables for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Jojelyn

texts.en:
Jojelyn P. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 36 years old. Jojelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jojelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothes in the local community. Jojelyn is just starting this business.

In 2008, Jojelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jojelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Jojelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jojelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and pay the tuition fees of her children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is already 56 years old. She is married to Paulino who is 68 years old and works as a simple farmer in their village. They are gifted with three children and they are so grateful because all of their children were able to finish their college education and are now working. Sometimes, their children assist them financially but Cristina does not want to depend too much on their children for their needs.

Cristina manages a village store and sells vegetables. She is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 15,000 as additional capital to further improve her simple enterprise hoping to eventually have an increase in income. She also wants her hog-raising business to be stable by maintaining their feed supply. She really wants to improve her sales to create a good income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Jomar

texts.en:
Jomar is managing a bakeshop where he sells hot “pandesal” (a soft bread famous in the Philippines, suitable for breakfast). Aside from selling bread, he also sells balut ( a fertilized duck egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and eaten in the shell. It is commonly sold as street food in the Philippines at night). Through his simple businesses, he is able to provide for the needs of his family. With his dream to make his business grow, he would like to borrow from Kiva lenders the amount of PHP 5,000.

He is working hard so he can help his parents and provide a better standard of living for his own family. He is married to Joverlyn and a loving father to his child Gian Carlo.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men P. is a 41-year-old and a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, where she earns a living by selling flowers for ceremonies and other parties at the local busy market. She married years ago and is blessed with two children, one of whom is married; the other one is dependent on her income. Her husband, San Hoy, age 41, is a military policeman.

Men P. will use her loan to order more different kinds of flowers to better meet her valued customers' requirements. She proposes to decorate and repair the roof of her house, using the rest of the loan. Men P. was not available when we came to take her photo, so her daughter was photographed instead.

loans.use: To order more different kinds of flowers for resale

loans.name: Ralph

texts.en:
Ralph N. is managing a motorcycle shop that sells motorcycle parts and they also cater some service. He is 23 years old and living in the village of San Leonardo of Aglipay, Quirino Province. He is very responsible and working hard for his future family.

In order to make his business more productive, he would like to borrow additional business capital amounting to PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. He hopes that through the loan, his business will continue to become more and more successful.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Hasna

texts.en: Hasna L. is from the village of Panduma Sr., Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 34 years old, is married, and has an infant child. Hasna owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Hasna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Hasna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma manages a general store business in their simple place at Barangay San Leonardo, Aglipay, Quirino. She is 23 years old and is happily married to Alfredo G.. Vilma is thankful because she is blessed with two children: Allan Klyne - 4 years old and Glenn - 1 year old.

Vilma wants to expand her business to generate a bigger daily income, especially since commodities nowadays are very costly. She is seeking the support of Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000. She will use the loan to improve her business.

According to Vilma, “hard work will make a business to improve your way of living.” She hopes that lenders will assist her in reaching her dreams. She is doing her best to succeed in life.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Tong

texts.en: Mr. Tong T. is a villager in Samraung village in Takeo province. He is a palm juice collector. His wife, Mrs. Kaem Nhy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where they cultivate rice. Although they try to work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support their household. Thus, Mr. Tong T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. He hopes to increase their income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. He has two children, one of whom is employed in a beer factory while the other stays at home to do housework. His wife is also present in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Jesusa is 58 years old. She and her family lives in San Lenorado, Aglipay, Quirino, Isabela. She is married to Benjamin who is a farmer. The couple is blessed with four children: two of them are already married while Emilyn - 35 years old is a graduate of a computer secretarial course and the youngest, Noven Rose - 22 years old, is a 2nd year college student. Jesusa is hoping that her youngest daughter will finish college in order to have a better job in the future. 

Jesusa wants to borrow from Kiva lenders PHP 5,000 that she will use for her glutinous rice and coconut-grinding business. Aside from grinding, alongside her grinding machine she sells rice cakes made from glutinous rice. She hopes her business will grow into a bigger one.

loans.use: To use as additional capital

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette A. is from the village of Gala, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Jeanette is single. To make a living, Jeanette owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jeanette has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jeanette joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeanette has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Jeanette is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Jeanette from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en: Mrs Sarom N. is from Ank Ta Nu village in Takeo province. She is 43 years old and the mother of nine children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, five of whom attend the local school, while the other two are too young to work or study. Sarom N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Although she and her husband, Mr Bao Shi, work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their household. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs Sarom N. has decided to ask for a loan. She will add it to her savings so that she can buy a motorbike for her husband to set up a motor taxi business. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to set up a motor taxi business

loans.name: Chay

texts.en: Chay C. is forty-one years old and married with two teenage children, who go to school and help their mother in her work as a fruit trader. Chay C. sells fruit that she buys in bulk from local growers and earns around $4 a day. She said that her income is not enough for her family’s expenses, so she depends on her husband’s income from his business, which is driving a motorbike taxi. Recently, her husband complains that he can’t generate much revenue because his motor often breaks. Therefore, Chay C. is applying for a loan to replace the motorbike and to purchase extra fruit for sale.

loans.use: To replace her husband’s taxi and to buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela lives with her family in Barangay Inaban Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She dreams of improving their current living situation, and through her business she is positive that she can achieve this dream.

She is engaged in the vending business, selling different commodities and snacks.  She hopes that with the income from her business she can continue to send her three children to school, and she hopes they will finish their college education. Carmela and her husband Gerardo are working hard to meet all the needs of their family.  

Carmela wants to improve her business, and this is why she needs a loan of PHP 10000 from the Kiva lenders. With this loan, she plans to purchase more merchandise, especially nutritious snacks. Her stall is located near the elementary school, so most of her customers are children.  She also wants to venture into the business of selling vegetables for additional income.  She hopes that lenders will grant her request, and she promises to pay back her loan on time.

loans.use: Additional business capital

location.town: Inaban Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Ny N. is a villager in Trapaing Ta Auy village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land for cultivating rice. She faces the problem of having infertile soil on her land, and she does not have enough money to buy fertilizer, nor to hire a laborer with oxen to plow her field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, for plowing, and to hire laborers to work in the field. Her husband, Ek Chhoeun, is a construction worker. Aside from this work, he is also a motorbike taxi driver. Ny is forty years old and the mother of three children who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown with her in this picture.

loans.use: For fertilizer, for plowing, and for laborers.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
“A man of perseverance lives progressively while a man of laziness lives downwardly” says Rosemarie of Barangay Inaban Dupax del Norte, in Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Eduardo and they have five children. Through their hard work and sacrifice, the couple have able to send their children to school. Two of their children are graduates of a vocational course and are presently working as security guards. The others are still in school. The couple continues to work hard so that their business will progress and they will be able to give their children a good future. 

Rosemarie helps her husband manage their rice-farming business, which is their only source of income.  She is requesting a loan of PHP10000 for the maintenance of their farm. She hopes that their income will grow because their family expenses are growing. Aside from farming, Rosemarie is also engaged in the direct-selling business of AVON cosmetics products, which helps provide for some of their needs.

loans.use: Additional working capital

location.town: Inaban Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Sari's Group

texts.en:
Sari A. is the group leader of six members who live in Prey Kla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice, and she also breeds chickens.  The soil on her rice field is infertile which affects her crop badly, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to plow the field. Sari is forty-three years old and a widow with one child who breeds cows. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans, so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans' term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients stA. to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to plow the field.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria E. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is seventy-six years old and a widow with five grown children. Gregoria's business is the planting and harvesting of coconut. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Gregoria joined GDMPC, one of Kiva's field partners, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Gregoria has successfully repaid previous loans from GDMPC. Now she is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her seventeenth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in the growth of her business

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Mom Ouch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people living in Chrouy Slaeng village in Takeo province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Srey Mom O. is the twenty-six-year-old village bank president. She owns a small grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more grocery products to sell. Her husband, Mr. Kim Chanthorn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice. He also uses a motorbike with a cA. to transport goods as well as to convey passengers for additional income. This couple has a child who is too young to work or study. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients stA. to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda is fifty-five years old and has eight children, six of whom are married.  One is currently studying in college while the other one has been helping on the farm since he stopped studying. According to Criselda, lack of money and interest are the main reasons why seven of her children did not complete even a high school education. Richard is the only one who is really willing to pursue his studies in college. That is why Criselda sacrifices a lot to earn income to pay for his education. Criselda is married to Antonio, who is a farmer.  They reside in the mountainous area of Cabisera 27, San Antonio Ilagan, Isabela.

Criselda manages a hog-raising business. Aside from this, she is also engaged in a rice-retailing business because income from her hogs occurs only every four months.  To further expand her business, Criselda is requesting a second loan of PHP6000 that she will use in her business. She plans to purchase one more piglet and a supply of feed as well as sacks of rice to sell. She is hoping for the development of her business through the loan which will be very beneficial for the attainment of her son’s education.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mrs. Sothea Prom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan which consists of sixteen people is located in Tuol Pongro village in Takeo province. Sothea P. is the village bank president, selected by the members. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Sam Auk, is a farmer who earns a living from his two hectares of land which are used for cultivating rice. His land is not very fertile, so Sothea decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to increase production. She is thirty-six years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Srey Yean C. does not come to take a loan but her husband does, so he is shown in the picture instead. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan's term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to increase production.

loans.name: Avelino

texts.en:
Avelino is a hog raiser in a village in Cabisera 27 San Antonio Ilagan, Isabela. He would like to request another loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP12000 to further help him raise his hogs. He will use the loan to buy at least two sacks of feed and for the family's needs at home. 

Aside from working as a hog raiser, he also works on his farm. He must work hard so he can provide for the needs of his family.  He hopes and prays that he will again be entrusted with the loan he is requesting.

Avelino is married to Constancia. His four children are: Gemalyn, who already graduated from her teaching course and is now a teacher; the twins, Geraldine and Mary Jane; and Rommel, who just finished the elementary level. His daughter Geraldine wants to pursue her studies in college and become a teacher like Gemalyn. Because of his daughter’s dream, Avelino strives to support her life's ambition, and is encouraged to work harder and to overcome the difficulties of life.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Mrs. Sy So Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people living in Ponley village in Takeo province comprise this village bank group loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sy S. is a 63-year-old village bank group president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn for living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is unfertilized and she does not have enough money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the rice field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to plow the field. Mrs. Sy S. is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the other attends the local school.   

All the members in this group loan are End-of-Term loans, S. they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and have the means to plow

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie P. is from the village of Curvada, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 40 years old. Elsie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Elsie owns and operates a pedicab transport service business. Elsie is just starting this business.

In 2009, Elsie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional vehicles for the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elsie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
